instruction: Generate conversational responses that reflect a thoughtful and insightful perspective on various topics. Each response should demonstrate clarity of thought and a focus on fundamental principles. Use the input prompt to inspire a reply that feels natural and engaging, while also conveying a deeper understanding of the subject.

training_data.input: Can you introduce the panelists for today's discussion?
training_data.output: Joining us today are Sonal Ved, a group digital editor based in Mumbai, India, and author of cookbooks such as 'Stiffin' and 'Indian Vegan', and Dina Begum, a British Bangladeshi author and food writer, whose new book is 'Made in Bangladesh'.

training_data.input: What's the current state of food writing, and how has it changed in recent years?
training_data.output: In the last few years, there's definitely been a shift in food writing, with clichés being called out and corrected by readers, especially in International Publications.

training_data.input: How do you see the identity of Indian food changing internationally?
training_data.output: I think there's a shift towards more nuanced food writing, focusing on regional food and practices, and pushing back against clichés and generalizations.

training_data.input: Can you elaborate on the changes you've observed in the way Indian food is perceived and written about in India?
training_data.output: In India, we've moved away from considering North Indian food as the hallmark of Indian cuisine, and there's a growing interest in understanding the differentiation between various regional cuisines, even within the subcontinent.

training_data.input: How are these changes reflected in the way Indian food is presented in restaurants?
training_data.output: Restaurants are now trying to incorporate these nuances into their menus, offering versions of regional specialties and reflecting the public's excitement about understanding the diversity of Indian cuisine.

training_data.input: What role do you see yourself playing in documenting these changes in Indian food culture?
training_data.output: As an author of cookbooks and food writer, I aim to capture these nuances and changes in my work, helping to promote a deeper understanding and appreciation of Indian cuisine.

training_data.input: What's your take on the current state of Indian food and food journalism?
training_data.output: There's a movement in Indian food, and we're no longer dumbing it down for people. Writers are expecting readers to be more evolved, and there's a sense of encouragement in the way Indian food is being written about.

training_data.input: How do you think Indian food is being perceived internationally versus locally?
training_data.output: While international media may still be struggling, locally we're being very particular about nuances like gender, ethnicity, origin of rituals, and ingredients, and there's a sense of responsibility in reporting.

training_data.input: As an editor, how do you approach encouraging writers to tackle complex subjects in Indian food?
training_data.output: I'm trying to encourage more writing and writers who want to talk with integrity and depth about any subject, rather than just brushing upon it and moving on to the next thing.

training_data.input: How do you think Bangladeshi cuisine has been perceived in relation to Indian and Pakistani cuisine?
training_data.output: There have been struggles and stereotypes in separating Bangladeshi cuisine from Indian and Pakistani, and I'm curious to hear from Dina about her work in this area.

training_data.input: What challenges did you face when writing about Bangladeshi food?
training_data.output: When I started writing full-time about food 10 years ago, there was very little written about Bangladeshi food in English internationally, and people had typical comments like 'isn't this the same as Indian food?'

training_data.input: How did you address the misconception that Bangladeshi food is the same as Indian food?
training_data.output: I explained that while visually a lot of South Asian food can look similar and have overlaps, the way they're cooked and the ingredients used are totally different and can transform a dish.

training_data.input: What inspired you to highlight Bangladeshi cuisine?
training_data.output: The book by Sumayya Usmani, which spotlighted Pakistani cuisine, was a huge revelation to me, and I thought it would be great if people saw Bangladeshi cuisine in the same way.

training_data.input: How did you see the interest in Regional South Asian Cuisine evolving?
training_data.output: Around 10 years ago, people from the UK were starting to get interested in more Regional South Asian Cuisine, including Regional Indian cuisine and Pakistani cuisine.

training_data.input: What inspired you to write about Bangladeshi food?
training_data.output: I was inspired by the response I received on social media when I wrote about Bangladeshi food, which encouraged me to explore the cuisine further.

training_data.input: Did you face any challenges when trying to publish your work on Bangladeshi food?
training_data.output: Yes, I faced challenges from publishers who thought people wouldn't be interested in Bangladeshi food, or that it was too similar to Indian food.

training_data.input: How did your first book, which featured a mix of Bangladeshi and immigrant cuisines, influence your decision to focus on Bangladeshi food?
training_data.output: The response to my first book motivated me to focus more on Bangladeshi food, which I had always wanted to write about since I was young.

training_data.input: What has been the response to your latest book on Bangladeshi food?
training_data.output: The response has been overwhelming, with people resonating with the stories, recipes, and memories shared in the book, which has cemented the idea that there is a need for this type of content.

training_data.input: What makes your cookbook unique in the mainstream English market?
training_data.output: It's an important book because we haven't had a Bangladeshi cookbook in the mainstream in English before, so it's an honor for me to write this and share it with everybody.

training_data.input: How do you respond to people who think Bangladeshi cuisine is hard to understand or similar to Indian or Pakistani cuisine?
training_data.output: I explain it with brief examples, like Fish and Rice being core staples, and then highlighting unique food traditions like Borta and Pitha, which are rice-based sweets and savories.

training_data.input: Can you give an example of how Borta is different in Bangladeshi cuisine compared to Indian or Pakistani cuisine?
training_data.output: While there's a similar dish called Benan Barta in Indian and Pakistani cuisine, the vast range of Borta in Bangladesh is a cornerstone of Bangladeshi cuisine, made with mustard oil, chilies, and coriander.

training_data.input: What are some key differentiating factors of Bangladeshi food compared to Indian and Pakistani cuisine?
training_data.output: I would say Fish, Rice, Barta, and Pitha are the differentiating factors of Bangladeshi food, giving a general overview of the cuisine.

training_data.input: How do you think international influences have shaped street food in different regions, including Bangladesh and Karachi?
training_data.output: I'm curious about the Regional International influences on street food, and I know from my experience that cities like Karachi have a ton of international influences on their cuisine, with examples like the burger and alui.

training_data.input: How do regional influences impact street food in Pakistan and India?
training_data.output: Regional influences from within Pakistan and India go into the making of street food, such as kebabs and sandwiches, and international food trends also play a role due to migration.

training_data.input: Can you elaborate on the evolution of Indian food over time?
training_data.output: Indian food is at least 4,000 years old, and its definition is constantly changing, with revisions happening every few hundred years, and we're currently experiencing a colossal shift in our attitude towards Indian cuisine.

training_data.input: How has the perception of street food changed in India?
training_data.output: Earlier, concepts like chaat and kebab rolls were considered down-market, but now Indian chefs, even in fine dining restaurants in cities like New York and London, are serving versions of these street food snacks.

training_data.input: What role has immigration played in shaping Indian street food?
training_data.output: Immigration is just one aspect of the evolution of Indian street food, and there are many other factors that have contributed to its growth and change.

training_data.input: Can you give an example of a popular street food dish in India that has been influenced by international trends?
training_data.output: The egg banjo, a dish being sold in a small town in Madhya Pradesh, is a supremely popular dish that has been influenced by international trends, such as the burger.

training_data.input: What's the story behind the popular dish 'Egg Banjo' in India?
training_data.output: It's inspired by the British snack 'Egg Banjo', an egg sandwich that originated around World War I, and has been adapted with Indian spices and flavors.

training_data.input: How has the dish 'Egg Banjo' been received in India?
training_data.output: It's being sold in central India as a unique and exciting street food, with everyone eating it, and it's an example of how Indian street food has always been influenced by external factors.

training_data.input: Can you give another example of how Indian street food has been influenced by external cultures?
training_data.output: There's 'Chinese Bale', which originated from the Indo-Chinese exchange in Kolkata in the late 1700s, where Chinese traders settled and Indians adapted their fried noodles with spices and other ingredients.

training_data.input: How have immigrants and external influences shaped Indian street food?
training_data.output: Immigrants from various countries, including the Portuguese, Chinese, Dutch, and British, have all had their influences on Indian street food, contributing to its unique flavors and diversity.

training_data.input: Do you see similar international influences on street food in Bangladesh and in Bangladeshi restaurants in the UK?
training_data.output: Yes, I'm curious to know if Dina has observed similar influences on street food in Bangladesh and in Bangladeshi restaurants in the UK, and if there are any British influences on Bangladeshi street food.

training_data.input: What's happening with Bangladeshi dishes in Dhaka?
training_data.output: Origin Bangladeshi dishes are now coming back to Dhaka in a circular way, with a bit more exchange between Bangladeshi food and the UK.

training_data.input: Can you give examples of this exchange?
training_data.output: PKA, Cho poty, and Shenara are street foods popular in Bangladesh that are now appearing in cafes in London and around the UK.

training_data.input: How is social media influencing this exchange?
training_data.output: People are traveling to Bangladesh, filming their food experiences, and sharing them on social media, which is translating into more Bangladeshi influences in UK menus.

training_data.input: What's the impact on Bangladeshi cuisine in the UK?
training_data.output: There's a growing celebration of Bangladeshi street food in the UK, with more Bangladesh influences appearing in mainstream dining areas.

training_data.input: How is this trend affecting Bangladesh?
training_data.output: People are taking greater pride in representing and showcasing their cuisine, with a greater celebration of Bangladeshi street food in mainstream dining areas.

training_data.input: What's your take on the influence of Western culture on food preferences in colonized countries?
training_data.output: I think in a lot of countries, especially those that have been colonized, there's a British influence, and people want to become Western, as it's seen as modern and desirable.

training_data.input: How do you think people are reclaiming their heritage and culture through food?
training_data.output: I think people are going back to their roots and reclaiming their heritage, culture, and food, and food is an easy way to share that with the world, as it doesn't require language or cultural knowledge.

training_data.input: What kind of influences are you seeing in the street food scene in Bangladesh?
training_data.output: I'm seeing a mix of Bangladesh street food, Indian street food, and other international influences, such as Chinese, Thai, and Korean cuisines, which is exciting and reflects the country's cultural diversity.

training_data.input: What do you think is driving the interest in showcasing original Bangladeshi food?
training_data.output: I think it's a combination of factors, including travel, social media, and a greater interest in sharing and recreating dishes, which is leading to a renewed focus on showcasing original Bangladeshi food.

training_data.input: How has social media impacted the way we experience street food culture?
training_data.output: It's incredible how many narrators we have of street food culture now in both urban and rural parts of the region, which I don't think we had access to at all before.

training_data.input: Can you give an example of how social media trends in street food are spreading across regions?
training_data.output: In Pakistan, we had a trend where a guy in Lahore would pour a gallon of kehwa onto any kind of food he was cooking, and people in Pakistan started copying it, and then I've seen videos of people in India commenting on this trend.

training_data.input: How is the 'Instagramification' or 'TikTokification' of street food changing the way we look at food in India?
training_data.output: We've always looked at cooking shows abroad and incorporated some of that, but now with Instagram and TikTok, we're seeing a new level of cultural encounters shaping the way we look at food.

training_data.input: How are traditional street foods being innovated and modified in India?
training_data.output: People are getting bored of eating the same versions of Pani Puri for centuries, so now they're doing six different kinds of panis for the six Puri that you get, with different flavors like raw mango, tamarind, and mint leaves.

training_data.input: How is innovation changing the concept of authentic Indian food?
training_data.output: The dialogue around what Indian food is, is changing and it's going to keep evolving, just like it has for centuries.

training_data.input: What role does social media play in influencing street food in India?
training_data.output: Instagram Reels has a massive influence on street food, especially in regions like Surat, where people are more experimental with their food.

training_data.input: Can you give an example of how street food vendors in India are incorporating international trends into their offerings?
training_data.output: In Surat, you can find street stalls selling avocado toast with an Indian twist, such as adding Indian cheese and spices, which is an example of the 'Instagram-ification' of street food.

training_data.input: How do international food trends make their way into Indian street food?
training_data.output: International trends, such as the blooming onion, make their way into Indian street food through social media platforms like Instagram, and then become available on the streets.

training_data.input: What's an example of a current international food trend that has become popular in India?
training_data.output: Boba tea is a huge trend that has now become available in small, hole-in-the-wall places in India, showing the influence of international trends on Indian street food.

training_data.input: How does international culture and cuisine impact your work?
training_data.output: It's something that's going to stick, but only time can tell, as it's very new to what we're experiencing.

training_data.input: How do people from the Bangladeshi diaspora react to your work on historical Bangladeshi cuisine?
training_data.output: I've had a lot of messages from not just Bangladeshis in the diaspora but other people as well who've been married into a Bangladeshi family or have actually lived or worked in Bangladesh.

training_data.input: How did you learn about traditional Bangladeshi cuisine despite growing up in the UK?
training_data.output: My family, especially my parents and grandmother, were very stringent on teaching us traditional Bangladeshi cuisine, not just the cooking but also the ingredients and where things come from.

training_data.input: How did your upbringing influence your connection to Bengali culture?
training_data.output: I grew up in a house where we spoke Bengali at home, and my dad was a huge advocate for Bangladeshi literature and culture, so I learned a lot from him and my mother.

training_data.input: What inspired you to write a book about Bangladeshi cuisine?
training_data.output: I grew up seeing the rich food culture of Bangladesh and wanted to share it with the world, especially since it's not well-known internationally.

training_data.input: How did you approach researching and writing the book?
training_data.output: I did my best to research everything through family, friends, and visits to Bangladesh, and I wanted to get it right to showcase the cuisine proudly.

training_data.input: What was your goal in sharing the recipes and food history in the book?
training_data.output: I wanted people to take away not just the recipes, but also learn about the food history, so it's not just about cooking, but also about understanding the culture.

training_data.input: How did you feel when people identified with the dishes and techniques you shared?
training_data.output: It was really touching, and when people said they cooked the dishes and tasted similar flavors, I knew I must have done something right.

training_data.input: How did you approach representing the diverse regions of Bangladesh in the book?
training_data.output: I tried to standardize a lot of things and picked a couple of dishes from each region to make it representative, not just of the capital city or one particular area.

training_data.input: What inspired you to incorporate different regions and seasons into your book?
training_data.output: I wanted to kind of incorporate all the different regions and um, you know, it's divided by Seasons, which is a huge part of the cultural landscape of Bangladeshi Cuisine.

training_data.input: How did you ensure that your book would resonate with readers who are familiar with Bangladeshi cuisine?
training_data.output: I wanted to get that so people could kind of relate to it, which hopefully they have, so yeah, that's kind of I guess it was uh very nice to see that you know people did relate to the recipes.

training_data.input: What was your experience like cooking Bangladeshi food for the first time?
training_data.output: I've never cooked Bangladeshi food and uh I think even cooking from I think one of the dishes that I cooked from your book, I thought okay I'm not going to compare this at all with Pakistani food like this is not the same thing.

training_data.input: How did you find the cooking techniques in Bangladeshi cuisine compared to what you were used to?
training_data.output: The cooking technique was completely different, like anything that I would have done in a normal recipe, it was completely the opposite of that.

training_data.input: What was the most challenging part of learning about Bangladeshi cuisine for you?
training_data.output: I had to really break a lot of my own stereotypes while cooking it and be like trust trust Dina, trust Dina, don't trust your own instincts of what you're supposed to do first.

training_data.input: Can you tell us about your research process for the book, particularly when it came to unlearning preconceived notions about Bangladeshi cuisine?
training_data.output: One of the things that you did for your book, um, who Samosa is it anyway, and I I know that there's obviously a lot of learning when you are doing archival research especially in our region about food, but how much of unlearning did you have to do about which you had already thought were kind of like you know your idea of like this this is exactly.

training_data.input: What was your experience like researching the origins of Indian food?
training_data.output: I found it eye-opening, especially as a vegetarian who grew up eating vegetarian food and thought that Indian food was mostly vegetarian, but it's actually not.

training_data.input: What did you learn about the diversity of Indian cuisine?
training_data.output: I realized that only about 39-40% of Indian food is vegetarian, and that there are many meat-eating regions with a vast catalog of meat recipes.

training_data.input: What common misconceptions about Indian food did you encounter?
training_data.output: One myth is that Indian food is only about spices, but there's so much more to it, and another myth is that Indian food is mostly vegetables and dal and paneer.

training_data.input: What regional variations of Indian cuisine did you discover?
training_data.output: I learned about the Northeast Indian food, which relies heavily on fresh greens and herbs to flavor their food, a very European way of cooking.

training_data.input: Who is an interesting historical figure you came across in your research?
training_data.output: Rabindra Tagore, a national leader, who I consider the first food influencer of India, as he was a big foodie and would go through phases of eating specific ingredients, like cauliflower.

training_data.input: What inspired your research on Indian food and culture?
training_data.output: Using a cauliflower, I would have never known this had it not been for the research of my book. I saw him, not just as a great writer of poetry, but also as someone who wrote copy for Cadbury.

training_data.input: Can you give an example of how your research led to unexpected discoveries?
training_data.output: I read about an Indian snack called sundal, which is basically chickpeas or peanuts sprinkled with coconut. It's been around for thousands of years, dating back to the Chola period, where a Chola Prince was depicted eating it in poetry.

training_data.input: How did your research for this book compare to your previous book, Tiffin?
training_data.output: I had just completed Tiffin, which was 500 Indian recipes, and then I started researching for this book. If I had done the research for this book before writing Tiffin, I think I would have had more than a thousand recipes.

training_data.input: What role did the Tagore family play in shaping Indian culture beyond poetry?
training_data.output: The Tagore family's influence extends to how we wear the modern sari, and if we started researching other areas, we would discover their influence on many modern aspects of our life.

training_data.input: What other areas of research have you explored, and what did you discover?
training_data.output: I started looking into the roots of a popular drink in urban Karachi and Punjab, and I was surprised by what I found.

training_data.input: What inspired you to research the origins of a popular drink in urban Karachi and Punjab?
training_data.output: I started looking into the roots of this very popular drink, milk mixed with Seven Up, and discovered it actually came from the Victorian era, not a Punjabi innovation as I had thought.

training_data.input: How did you approach researching for your book, and what role did oral tradition play in it?
training_data.output: Most of it came from collecting recipes from my teens, and a lot was passed down from my family, especially my mom and dad, who taught me to cook through sensory experience and feeling.

training_data.input: What was the biggest challenge you faced in writing down traditional family recipes?
training_data.output: I had to unlearn the natural way of cooking and start measuring, weighing, and timing things, which was tricky for me, as I was used to cooking by eye and rough estimates.

training_data.input: What was the biggest challenge in writing down your family recipes?
training_data.output: It was trying to get them to stand by my side and see how things should look, how much of this and that, and timing things.

training_data.input: How did you ensure the flavors in your recipes remained authentic?
training_data.output: I didn't dial down the chilies or spices, and I made a note that readers can always reduce the heat if they can't tolerate it.

training_data.input: What was the driving force behind your desire to get the recipes right?
training_data.output: I felt a little bit of pressure, as nobody in our family had written a book like this before, and I wanted things to be right as much as I could.

training_data.input: Who did you consult with during the research process for your book?
training_data.output: I spoke to my aunts, my late grandmother, my dad, and other family members and friends who shared their recipes and cooking techniques with me.

training_data.input: How did your upbringing influence the diversity of recipes in your book?
training_data.output: Growing up, we would visit people's houses for dinner and they would come over to ours, so there was a lot of sharing of recipes and different cooking styles.

training_data.input: What inspired you to focus on traditional recipes?
training_data.output: I was inspired by Chef Musa Dağdeviren's episode on Chef's Table, where he emphasized the importance of putting down the foundation of a cuisine before innovating.

training_data.input: How did you approach preserving traditional techniques and ingredients?
training_data.output: I spoke to elders in the community to get their input and ideas, and aimed to adapt traditional methods to modern kitchens while keeping the techniques and ingredients as traditional as possible.

training_data.input: How did you balance traditional methods with modern kitchen tools?
training_data.output: I made some adjustments, such as using a spice grinder or food processor when necessary, but tried to keep the techniques and ingredients as traditional as possible.

training_data.input: What inspired you to replicate traditional kitchen utensils and methods in your cooking?
training_data.output: My mother had all those traditional kind of kitchen utensils and things that she used in the kitchen, so I grew up seeing all of that and how those were used.

training_data.input: How do you think traditional recipes are passed down through generations?
training_data.output: When parents or Elders tell you recipes, you're meant to use your own mind, and there's not a lot of exact measurements, it's more about using your judgment.

training_data.input: Can you share an example of a recipe that was difficult to replicate due to the lack of exact measurements?
training_data.output: My father recently sent me a recipe that said 'count to five' and I was confused, it's like, what speed am I counting to five on?

training_data.input: How do you think the use of exact measurements affects the cooking process?
training_data.output: In South Asian cooking, it's more about doing things by eye, and using exact measurements can be seen as strange, like when my aunt's cook was surprised that I was asking for measurements in tablespoons.

training_data.input: What was the most challenging part of writing a recipe book for an American audience?
training_data.output: Specifying exact measurements, like how many spoons of flour to use to make a chapati, was the hardest thing I had to do, because it's not how we typically cook.

training_data.input: How did you overcome the challenge of measuring ingredients for a recipe book?
training_data.output: I had to actually measure how many spoons of flour I was taking, and now I know that it takes one heaped tablespoon to make one chapati, which I'll never forget.

training_data.input: How do you define 'heaped' when it comes to measuring ingredients?
training_data.output: That's a good question, even I would ask, how heaped, it's a subjective measurement that can vary from person to person.

training_data.input: How do you define a 'heaped' tablespoon in cooking?
training_data.output: I think I should not ever write a cookbook because I would be a complete disaster, but to answer your question, I'm not sure, is that mountain heaped or just like a normal sized heap?

training_data.input: What inspired you to structure your book around seasons?
training_data.output: We structured it around seasons because many South Asian cuisines, including Bangladeshi, eat seasonally and use local ingredients, which is important for the flavor and authenticity of the dishes.

training_data.input: Can you elaborate on the significance of seasonality in Bangladeshi cuisine?
training_data.output: Seasonality has a lot to do with what's available in different parts of Bangladesh, and there are huge differences in terms of spices used, ingredients used, and cooking styles from the north to the south.

training_data.input: What are some unique ingredients used in Bangladeshi cuisine that are influenced by its geography and cultural exchange?
training_data.output: There's a lot of Southeast Asian influences coming in from neighboring Myanmar, as well as Mogul, Persian, and British influences, which is reflected in the use of local ingredients like shatora, a bitter and aromatic spice used in meat dishes, dal, and fish.

training_data.input: How did your upbringing and cultural background influence your understanding of seasonality in cooking?
training_data.output: Growing up, I read about the six seasons in Bengali textbooks, and my dad always talked about the harvest seasons, summers, monsoons, and autumn, which instilled in me an appreciation for the importance of seasonality in cooking.

training_data.input: What inspired you to organize your book around the six seasons of Bengali culture?
training_data.output: Seasons where you make a lot of the P which are the rice based sweets and savories made with the freshly kind of um milled rice you know because it's harvest season so that's kind of a celebration around that harvest season.

training_data.input: Can you elaborate on the significance of these celebrations in Bengali culture?
training_data.output: There celebrations for everything literally and six seasons each of the season has multiple you know celebrations and um I grew up seeing that you know seeing the kind of illustrations in these textbooks you know um as well as my dad talking about it.

training_data.input: How did your upbringing influence your decision to center the book around these seasonal celebrations?
training_data.output: I think for me it was just trying to center it around something that was kind of nostalgic for me as well as something that was um culturally kind of approp because I just thought you know it just goes in with the feeds into the way we eat you know.

training_data.input: What do you hope readers take away from the cultural elements woven throughout the book?
training_data.output: I thought it's a nice way to structure the book because it's not just you know vegetarian meat fish you know dessert it's something that also brings in the cultural elements of bangl food culture and food history.

training_data.input: How do you balance the presentation of traditional Bengali culture with the recipes and food aspects of the book?
training_data.output: I had elements of the traditional Fabrics traditional kind of um props and things I've used if.

training_data.input: What inspired you to include various cultural elements in your book?
training_data.output: I wanted to showcase the culture of Bangladesh, not just the food culture, but the culture and history of Bangladesh, which is very important.

training_data.input: How do you think these cultural elements enhance the book?
training_data.output: I think it makes the book a much more fascinating read, and it's why I included six seasons in the book.

training_data.input: You mentioned a conversation with an Indian Chef, Rir BR, about corrupted versions of street food. Can you elaborate on that?
training_data.output: I was discussing how some chefs preserve traditional recipes, while others experiment with modern twists, like Dosa filled with Momos.

training_data.input: How do you think traditional recipes can coexist with modern variations?
training_data.output: Rir BR said there's space for both kinds of chefs, and I agree. Some people will want to preserve traditional recipes, while others will want to innovate.

training_data.input: How does your approach to preserving traditional recipes relate to your cookbook?
training_data.output: I try to preserve these recipes so that they're there, like they're a part of our heritage, and I think that's what Dena is trying to do as well.

training_data.input: How do you think the evolution of cuisine affects traditional recipes?
training_data.output: Evolution or whatever you want to call it is something that you know we're not going to be able to stop because as more and more ingredients begin to come into any Cuisine or any land people are going to experiment with it.

training_data.input: Can you give an example of how external influences have shaped a traditional cuisine?
training_data.output: Indian Cuisine does not have the concept of macaroni but there is a Cindi dish which is called macaroni patata which is basically a subg made out of macaroni and potatoes and spices.

training_data.input: How do you think new recipes are incorporated into a traditional cuisine?
training_data.output: Now this recipe must be in Indian Cuisine for say 20 years 30 years or so but it has now become a part of Indian Cuisine so you don't know what sticks and then kind of lasts.

training_data.input: What factors determine whether a new recipe becomes a lasting part of a traditional cuisine?
training_data.output: Some things will paid away because they just don't make any sense uh to the cuisine the ingredient availability is there's a shortage and things like that um but then there will be things which will kind of stay and only time can tell decide or the pallet will decide.
